childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1995-2007

You were born the year the Oklahoma City bombing happened and O.J. Simpson was found not guilty—two events that would define your generation's relationship with domestic terror and celebrity justice for decades to come. Bill Clinton was in the White House, wearing out the rug between the Oval Office and the scandal. The Unabomber was still sending packages. Timothy McVeigh had just murdered 168 people in a federal building.

Your childhood was the peak of the '90s economic boom. Your parents probably thought things were getting better. Unemployment was low. The stock market was high. The internet was this weird new thing that made screeching noises and took forever to load a single photo. By the time you were in kindergarten, everyone was panicking about Y2K.

You were six when 9/11 happened. You probably watched it on a TV in a classroom, or came home to adults who looked scared in ways you didn't understand. The before-and-after of that day split your childhood in half. Everything after felt different—more afraid, more surveilled, more uncertain.

You grew up with VHS tapes and DVD players in the same house. You had a Gameboy, then a Gameboy Color, then a Gameboy Advance. You played outside until the streetlights came on, but you also spent hours on Neopets and Club Penguin. You were analog enough to remember it, digital enough to not miss it.

Your childhood ended with the 2008 financial crisis. You were thirteen. You probably didn't understand mortgage-backed securities, but you understood when your parents started worrying about money, when friends moved away because their families lost their houses, when 'the economy' became a thing adults talked about the way they used to talk about the weather.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

You're a Millennial, born between 1981 and 1996. You're at the very end of that range, which means you have more in common with older Gen Z than with elder Millennials born in the early '80s. Some researchers call your micro-generation 'Zillennials'—old enough to remember life before smartphones, young enough to have grown up on social media.

The Millennial generation is roughly 72 million people in the US, making it the largest cohort until Gen Z started catching up. You're part of the demographic wave that marketers obsessed over, think pieces pathologized, and employers exploited.

9/11 is still your generation's defining moment, even though you were only six. You don't remember the before times as clearly as older Millennials do, but you grew up in the after times. The security theater, the endless wars, the ambient anxiety—that was just normal to you.

You graduated high school in 2013, which meant you missed the worst of the 2008 job market but inherited its consequences. College was more expensive than ever. Entry-level jobs demanded experience you couldn't get. The economy 'recovered' in ways that mainly benefited people who were already rich.

Your generation gets blamed for killing industries, but mostly you just can't afford what older generations took for granted. You didn't kill homeownership—you can't afford it. You didn't kill diamonds—you're paying off student loans. The accusations of being entitled are particularly rich coming from generations that had pensions and affordable housing.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Toy Story came out—the first fully computer-animated feature film. That feels metaphorically appropriate. You're the generation that watched animation evolve from hand-drawn to digital, that saw special effects go from practical to CGI, that experienced the entire media landscape transform from physical to streaming.

1995 was peak '90s. Coolio's 'Gangsta's Paradise' dominated the radio. Alanis Morissette was telling us what irony wasn't. TLC was warning about waterfalls. Clueless defined a generation's vocabulary. Batman Forever proved you could ruin a franchise with neon and nipples.

Your childhood was the Disney Renaissance's last gasp and the early Pixar era. You watched Pocahontas and Hercules in theaters. You wore out VHS tapes of The Lion King. By the time you were old enough to have opinions, Shrek was making fun of everything you'd grown up on.

Your middle school years belonged to emo music, MySpace, and the rise of YouTube. You probably had a screen name you're now embarrassed by and an away message that was song lyrics. Your high school years were the early iPhone era, the Obama era, the beginning of streaming destroying cable.

You're the last generation to remember renting movies from Blockbuster, to experience the communal anticipation of a TV show airing once a week, to understand why 'Be Kind, Rewind' mattered. You're also young enough that binge-watching feels completely natural. You're bilingual in old media and new media, which is a weird skill that gets less useful every year.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Windows 95 launched with a $300 million marketing campaign that included the Rolling Stones' 'Start Me Up.' Microsoft bought the world's attention to sell them a Start button. Bill Gates was the richest person alive. The internet was about to change everything, and most people still didn't have email.

eBay launched in 1995. So did Craigslist, Amazon (as a bookstore), and Java. The web was ugly, slow, and revolutionary. By the time you were old enough to use it, Google existed and Ask Jeeves was already a joke.

You were five when the dot-com bubble burst. Eleven when Twitter launched. Twelve when the iPhone came out. You didn't get a smartphone until you were a teenager, which makes you different from Gen Z, who got them in elementary school. You remember the world before everyone had a computer in their pocket.

Facebook opened to the public when you were eleven. By the time you were in high school, it was how you socialized. By college, it was how you organized protests and shared news. Now it's where your relatives post misinformation and you visit once a year to see birthday notifications.

Your relationship with technology is intimate but not native. You learned to type on keyboards, not touchscreens. You remember downloading music illegally on Napster and then Limewire, waiting hours for a single song. You've watched technology go from a tool you used to an environment you live in. You can still imagine life without it, which gives you perspective younger generations don't have.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were four months old when the Oklahoma City bombing killed 168 people, including 19 children in a daycare. You don't remember it, but it shaped the security state you grew up in. Before that bombing, federal buildings were open. After, they were fortresses. Domestic terrorism was supposed to be unthinkable. You were born into a world learning it wasn't.

You were six when planes hit the towers. You were thirteen during the 2008 financial crisis. Eighteen when Sandy Hook happened—children your age just seven years earlier, murdered in their classroom. Twenty during the Pulse nightclub shooting. Twenty-two when Parkland happened and students your age led a national movement.

You grew up during the longest wars in American history. Afghanistan started when you were six. You were twenty-six when it ended in chaotic withdrawal. Twenty years of war that accomplished nothing, fought by people only slightly older than you while you watched from home.

You were eighteen when Obama was elected—the first Black president, a moment that felt historic and hopeful. You were twenty-one when Trump was elected, which felt like history going backward. You were twenty-five during the pandemic, which killed over a million Americans and rewrote the rules of work, school, and daily life.

Your generation has lived through more 'unprecedented' events than any since the Greatest Generation. You've normalized mass shootings, economic collapse, and pandemic death. This isn't resilience—it's damage. You've adapted because you had no choice, not because adaptation is a virtue.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You graduated college around 2017, into an economy that had technically recovered from 2008 but hadn't fixed any of the underlying problems. Jobs existed. Good jobs with benefits and stability were harder to find. The gig economy was sold as 'flexibility' when it was really 'no benefits and inconsistent income.'

You entered the workforce during the era of open offices, beer fridges, and companies calling themselves 'families' while offering no job security. You've probably worked somewhere with a ping pong table and a CEO who talks about culture while paying below market rate.

COVID hit when you were around 25—early career, still establishing yourself. Suddenly you were working from your bedroom, attending Zoom meetings in real pants and pajama bottoms, watching entire industries collapse while tech companies posted record profits. Remote work became permanent, which was great for flexibility and terrible for boundaries.

Your generation job-hops because companies don't reward loyalty. Average tenure is two to three years. You've learned that the only way to get a raise is to leave. You've watched colleagues do the same work as you for twice the salary because they negotiated better or got hired when the market was hot.

You're probably dealing with some combination of student debt, rising rent, and the nagging sense that no matter how hard you work, you're falling behind. The math doesn't work. You know it. Employers know it. Everyone pretends not to notice while asking you to demonstrate 'passion' in your cover letters.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Tinder launched when you were seventeen. By the time you were seriously dating, swipe-based apps were normal. You might have met partners in person, through friends, at school—but you've definitely also met them through apps. The algorithm is part of your romantic history whether you like it or not.

You communicate primarily through text and DMs. Phone calls feel aggressive. Voicemails are a relic. You can have entire relationships—flirtation, commitment, breakup—without ever hearing someone's voice. This is both convenient and slightly dystopian.

Your generation has delayed marriage and kids more than any before. Part of it is financial—weddings cost money, kids cost more, housing is impossible. Part of it is cultural—the pressure to follow a traditional timeline has loosened. Part of it is practical—you want to be established before you add dependents, but getting established keeps taking longer.

You maintain friendships across distances through group chats and social media. Your best friend might live three time zones away. You might see your college roommate once a year but talk to them daily. Geography matters less than it used to, which is good for maintaining connections and bad for building community where you actually live.

You've probably been in a long-distance relationship at some point, made possible by FaceTime and cheap flights. You've probably also experienced the weird loneliness of being hyperconnected online while feeling isolated in person. Connection and loneliness coexist in ways previous generations didn't have to navigate.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were thirteen during the 2008 financial crisis—old enough to understand that something terrible was happening, young enough for it to shape your entire relationship with money. You watched adults lose jobs, lose houses, lose retirement savings. You learned early that stability is an illusion.

You graduated into a job market still recovering from that crash. College cost more than ever. Wages hadn't kept up with inflation. Housing prices climbed while you tried to pay off debt and save for a down payment that kept getting further away.

Your generation's financial anxiety is often dismissed as entitlement by people who bought houses for $60,000 in 1985. The math is different now. A median home costs over $400,000. Student loans average $30,000 and often exceed $100,000. Healthcare is tied to employment. The safety net has holes you could drive a truck through.

You probably have a complicated relationship with investing. You've seen the market crash multiple times. You don't trust it. But Social Security might not exist when you retire, so what's the alternative? You're gambling on a system you know is rigged because not gambling means losing for certain.

Financial wellness content tells you to skip the latte and invest the difference. This advice is insulting. You're not broke because of lattes. You're broke because wages stagnated while costs exploded, and an entire generation got stuck holding the bag. The math doesn't work, and no amount of budgeting apps can fix systemic failure.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation confuses online engagement with real-world action. You're great at hashtags, terrible at voter turnout. You can mobilize a million retweets for a cause and then not show up to the local election that would actually change something. Digital activism feels like activism, but feelings aren't policy.

You've been so thoroughly trained to cope with dysfunction that you sometimes forget to fight it. You normalize burnout. You accept that healthcare comes from employers, that education requires debt, that housing is unaffordable. You've adapted to a broken system so well that you've stopped demanding it be fixed.

You're so steeped in irony that sincerity feels risky. You can't just care about something—you have to care about it with self-aware distance, with acknowledgment of its problems, with protective layers of humor. This makes it hard to advocate for yourself without hedging. It makes earnest enthusiasm feel naive.

Your generation's self-deprecation has become its own kind of toxic positivity. Joking about being broke, being anxious, being exhausted—it's relatable, but it also lets you avoid actually addressing the problems. Laughing about your suffering isn't the same as changing your circumstances.

You're so used to being online that you underestimate how much offline life matters. The friends you text daily aren't the same as friends you see weekly. The communities you belong to on social media aren't the same as communities rooted in physical place. You know this intellectually, but the pull of the screen is strong, and real-world connection takes more effort.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2015-2025): You've spent this decade establishing yourself, or trying to. You graduated into a functional but unequal economy. You probably changed jobs several times, looking for something that paid enough and didn't crush your soul—a combination that's harder to find than it should be. COVID hit in the middle of this decade and reshuffled everything. You learned to work from home, lost social connections, maybe moved somewhere cheaper. You're ending your 20s with more clarity about what you want and more frustration about what's available.

Your 30s (2025-2035): You're entering this decade now. This is supposedly when things stabilize—career traction, maybe a long-term partner, possibly kids if that's what you want. But stability feels more precarious than it did for previous generations at this age. Housing is still unaffordable. The job market is volatile. You're building a life on shifting ground, which requires constant adjustment. The upside: you're experienced enough now to know what you're doing. The downside: you know exactly how hard it is.

Your 40s (2035-2045): Peak earning years, statistically. You'll have more authority at work, more confidence in your identity, more acceptance of what you can and can't change. Your parents will be aging, which brings new responsibilities. If you have kids, they'll be teenagers—which is its own challenge. You'll be the senior person in rooms where you used to be the youngest. That shift changes how people treat you and what they expect from you.

Your 50s (2045-2055): By now you'll have lived through at least five economic crises, one or two pandemics, and however many 'once in a generation' events. You'll be thinking about retirement but probably unable to retire. You'll be mentoring people who don't remember a time before smartphones. You'll find yourself telling stories about the old days—pre-smartphone, pre-streaming, pre-remote work—and watching younger people's eyes glaze over. You'll understand, finally, why older people always talked about how different things used to be.

Your 60s and beyond (2055+): The world will be unrecognizable. Climate change will have reshaped where and how people live. Technology will have advanced in ways that are hard to predict. You'll be part of the generation that remembers the transition—from analog to digital, from stable climate to crisis, from economic optimism to permanent precarity. Whether you retire traditionally, work part-time, or rely on kids and community depends on factors that are still being determined. The one certainty is uncertainty. You've been living with that your whole life.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.9 million people born in 1995. The entire Millennial generation is about 72 million people in the US. You're at the tail end of that generation, which puts you in a unique position—old enough to share formative experiences with elder Millennials, young enough to relate to Gen Z.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you're more educated, more diverse, and significantly poorer relative to where they were at your age. Gen X came of age during economic expansion. You came of age during the aftermath of collapse. They had affordable college. You have debt. They had career ladders. You have gig work.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the wealth gap is absurd. Boomers controlled 21% of the nation's wealth when they were your age. Millennials control about 7%. Boomers bought houses on a single income. You can't afford one on two incomes. The lifestyle they took for granted is a fantasy you watch in old movies.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you share more than you differ. You both grew up with the internet. You both entered adulthood during crises. But you remember life before smartphones. They don't. You had a childhood largely offline. They were posting on social media before they could read. You're slightly more optimistic, or at least you remember a time when optimism made sense.

Your life expectancy is around 78-80 years, which is actually lower than it should be. Your generation has higher rates of 'deaths of despair'—suicide, overdose, alcohol-related death—than previous generations did at your age. Mental health outcomes are worse. Anxiety and depression are more common. The world you inherited is harder, and it shows.

But you're also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of systemic injustice than any generation before. You've pushed for equity, destigmatized mental health, and refused to accept what previous generations considered inevitable. The world is worse in some ways and better in others, and you're part of the reason for both.

year_events: Toy Story released (first fully CGI film)
